title: Radiation Shielding Materials and Effectiveness
brief: Understanding which materials provide effective protection from nuclear radiation.
steps: Step 1: Use the densest materials available - lead, iron, concrete, and water are most effective.
Step 2: Apply the half-value layer principle: each additional layer of the same thickness cuts radiation by half.
Step 3: Use 1 meter of dirt to reduce 1,000 cgys per hour to about 0.5 cgy per hour inside shelter.
Step 4: Stack materials in layers - 5cm of brick reduces radiation by half, 10cm reduces to one-fourth.
Step 5: Prioritize underground shelters with 1+ meters of earth coverage.
Step 6: Seek caves, storm cellars, culverts, or basements of stone/mud buildings if available.
warnings: Thin roofing provides very little shielding benefit.
Time spent gathering shielding materials must be weighed against radiation exposure.
The denser the material, the better - but any shielding is better than none.
source: FM 21-76 US Army Survival Manual ‚Äî U.S. Department of the Army (Chapter 23 - Survival in Man-Made Hazards)
